articles.headline: Biden Warns Israel It Is ‘Losing Support’ Over War
articles.snippet: The president’s words exposed a widening rift between his administration and that of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu as casualties rise in Gaza.
articles.abstract: The president’s words exposed a widening rift between his administration and that of Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu as casualties rise in Gaza.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden told Israel’s leaders on Tuesday that they were losing international support for their war in Gaza, exposing a widening rift with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu, who rejected out of hand the American vision for a postwar resolution to the conflict.

articles.headline: Google’s Antitrust Loss to Epic Could Preview Its Legal Fate in 2024
articles.snippet: A trio of antitrust cases on the docket threaten to reshape Google’s business and sap its profits.
articles.abstract: A trio of antitrust cases on the docket threaten to reshape Google’s business and sap its profits.
articles.lead_paragraph: Google’s loss was swift after a monthlong antitrust trial in a San Francisco federal court. A little more than three hours after a jury had begun deliberating on Monday, they returned with their verdict.

articles.headline: Under Rules of War, ‘Proportionality’ in Gaza Is Not About Evening the Score
articles.snippet: The concept, important for determining the legality of an act of war, is about weighing civilian harm against military objectives, not about achieving a balanced number of casualties.
articles.abstract: The concept, important for determining the legality of an act of war, is about weighing civilian harm against military objectives, not about achieving a balanced number of casualties.
articles.lead_paragraph: The international laws governing war are unfeeling. They give more precedence to military advantage than to civilian harm. They do not consider comparative numbers of dead or wounded. They ask commanders in the field to judge, often very quickly, the military advantage of an attack, the nature of the threat they face, what means they possess to counter it and what feasible measures they can take to reduce the expected damage to civilians and civilian infrastructure.

articles.headline: Political Debate Is Rife on TikTok. Politicians? Not So Much.
articles.snippet: Very few politicians, including the top candidates for president, are on the hugely popular video app — perhaps ceding much of the political discussion to others.
articles.abstract: Very few politicians, including the top candidates for president, are on the hugely popular video app — perhaps ceding much of the political discussion to others.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Biden and the White House regularly post to millions of followers on social media, talking about the economy on Facebook, sharing Christmas decorations on YouTube, showcasing pardoned turkeys on Instagram, posting about infrastructure on the X platform. They’re even on Threads.

articles.headline: Cheating Fears Over Chatbots Were Overblown, New Research Suggests
articles.snippet: A.I. tools like ChatGPT did not boost the frequency of cheating in high schools, Stanford researchers say.
articles.abstract: A.I. tools like ChatGPT did not boost the frequency of cheating in high schools, Stanford researchers say.
articles.lead_paragraph: Last December, as high school and college students began trying out a new A.I. chatbot called ChatGPT to manufacture writing assignments, fears of mass cheating spread across the United States.

articles.headline: House Approves Biden Impeachment Inquiry as G.O.P. Hunts for an Offense
articles.snippet: Republicans are pushing forward with a formal investigation even though their yearlong scrutiny of the president and his family has turned up no evidence of high crimes or misdemeanors.
articles.abstract: Republicans are pushing forward with a formal investigation even though their yearlong scrutiny of the president and his family has turned up no evidence of high crimes or misdemeanors.
articles.lead_paragraph: The House voted on Wednesday to formally open an impeachment inquiry into President Biden, pushing forward with a yearlong G.O.P. investigation that has failed to produce evidence of anything approaching high crimes or misdemeanors.

articles.headline: Fed Leaves Rates Unchanged and Signals Three Cuts Next Year
articles.snippet: Federal Reserve policymakers left rates unchanged and projected three quarter-point rate cuts in 2024 as their inflation outlook improved.
articles.abstract: Federal Reserve policymakers left rates unchanged and projected three quarter-point rate cuts in 2024 as their inflation outlook improved.
articles.lead_paragraph: Federal Reserve officials left interest rates unchanged in their final policy decision of 2023 and forecast that they will cut borrowing costs three times in the coming year, a sign that the central bank is shifting toward the next phase in its fight against rapid inflation.

articles.headline: Inside the Troll Army Waging Trump’s Online Campaign
articles.snippet: A team of meme-makers has been flooding social media with pro-Trump posts riddled with sexist and racist tropes. Donald Trump is cheering them on.
articles.abstract: A team of meme-makers has been flooding social media with pro-Trump posts riddled with sexist and racist tropes. Donald Trump is cheering them on.
articles.lead_paragraph: The video, called “Let’s Get Ready to Bumble,” is a slick mash-up of President Biden’s verbal slip-ups and his stumbles set to a thumping 1990s dance track. And when it was played on a big screen at Trump rallies late last year, it consistently drew laughs and jeers from the crowd.

articles.headline: How Meta’s New Face Camera Heralds a New Age of Surveillance
articles.snippet: Meta’s $300 smart glasses look cool but lack a killer app, and they offer a glimpse into a future with even less privacy and more distraction.
articles.abstract: Meta’s $300 smart glasses look cool but lack a killer app, and they offer a glimpse into a future with even less privacy and more distraction.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the past two weeks, I’ve been using a new camera to secretly snap photos and record videos of strangers in parks, on trains, inside stores and at restaurants. (I promise it was all in the name of journalism.) I wasn’t hiding the camera, but I was wearing it, and no one noticed.

articles.headline: Tesla Recalls Autopilot Software in 2 Million Vehicles
articles.snippet: Federal regulators pressed the automaker to make updates to ensure drivers are paying attention while using Autopilot, a system that can steer, accelerate and brake on its own.
articles.abstract: Federal regulators pressed the automaker to make updates to ensure drivers are paying attention while using Autopilot, a system that can steer, accelerate and brake on its own.
articles.lead_paragraph: Tesla’s reputation for making technologically advanced cars suffered a blow on Tuesday when the company, under pressure from regulators, recalled more than two million vehicles. U.S. officials said the automaker had not done enough to ensure that drivers remained attentive when using a system that can steer, accelerate and brake cars automatically.
articles.byline: By Jack Ewing, Cade Metz and Derrick Bryson Taylor
